For the last entry, here's a more dramatic and elegant way of saying the same (accordign to chatGPT)

Today marks 100 consecutive days on LeetCode - a milestone that should feel triumphant. And yet, I can't help but smile wryly. The past week has been less about growth and more about just crossing the finish line, submitting the same accepted solution each day just to keep the streak alive.

✒️ How to Develop an Elegant, Thoughtful Writing Tone

That introspective, articulate tone you admire can absolutely become second nature. Here's a structured way to build it:

🧠 1. Read Writing with That Tone

To write elegantly, you must first absorb elegance.

✍️ Writers to Explore:

  • Paul Graham – Essays on thinking and life
  • Ali Abdaal – Blogs and newsletter
  • Austin Kleon – “Show Your Work”
  • Oliver Burkeman – “Four Thousand Weeks”
  • Naval Ravikant – Short‑form wisdom (tweets, podcast quotes)

Practice: Every day or two, read a short piece by any of these authors. Pay attention not just to what they say, but how they say it — rhythm, vocabulary, restraint, and structure.

✍️ 2. Freewrite in a Journal Daily (Short but Honest)

Write a short reflection at the end of the day — just one paragraph is enough.

💡 Prompt Ideas:

  • “What did I pretend not to notice today?”
  • “Where did I cut corners, and why?”
  • “What’s something small that deserves applause today?”

This habit builds clarity, self‑awareness, and your authentic voice.

🧱 3. Rewrite Casual Thoughts with Elevated Language

Take a simple thought and rewrite it like you're crafting a thoughtful blog or memoir entry.

Example:

  • Plain: “I just kept submitting the same solution for the last week.”
  • Elevated: “For the past week, it wasn’t progress I chased — just the illusion of it. The same stale solution, submitted like a daily ritual, kept the flame alive.”

Do this regularly. It trains narrative instinct and word economy.

🧰 4. Keep a ‘Tone Toolkit’

Maintain a personal Notion, Obsidian, or text file where you collect:

  • Phrases or metaphors you like
  • Elegant sentence openers
  • Quotes that match the vibe you’re aiming for

This is your go‑to vault whenever your writing feels flat or rushed.

🕰️ 5. Let It Happen Gradually

The goal is not to sound “smart” — it’s to sound authentically you, just with more grace and clarity.

🔁 Review Habit:

  • Revisit old reflections or notes weekly.
  • Ask: “How would I say this now?”

Mail dekh, SAP ke course ke liye 35,000 pay krne hai kal tk

A really funny thing happened yesterday.

So, there's our college, launching a SAP course for the students without half of the students not even knowing about this, Typical SRM behaviour... Anyways... I was really interested to take up that course and continue my SAP journey but yet again, this is SRM we are talking about, the deadline for the course was 10AM and they already closed the form by 9:28. I even shared the screenshot of the same and raised the query to the mentro s and whereever I could but, don't forget, this is SRM we are talking about, No response
A few weeks have passed and yesterday, my teacher shared a document stating the compensatory course fees is to be paid by the students possitively. Later someone called me, I won't say the name but for reference, it was from RA2311003030193. Ahem Ahem! So, the person on the other side of the phone told me that the course form has been opened again and you have to 35k or so to avail the course. I was shoched! simply shocked but deep inside I also had an intuition that on surplus request, they might have opened the form again. Yeah, and the person also said that we have got a mail and mentor replied to my query about the course. I was so into the thing to get the course that I checked my mail twice and found nothing. Later I realised that the person was thinking that message shared by the mentor is a reply to my message whereas it was just a message that the mentor had to share in the group. The way panic struck on that side of the call, I still find it really funny to know that someone can be this naive.
Anyways, someone other than me in my year also knows about SAP and knows it's worth. What really should I do to stand out then?

I'm still in doubt, not in doubt but pretty sure actually, that they might me wondering and still thinking and more overly, still inquiring here and there to get to know that this course is still open and they can enroll to this.

How to Set Up a Local Git Repository and Push to GitHub

This guide outlines the steps to initialize a local Git repository and push your code to a new GitHub repository. It is assumed that Git is already installed on your system and configured with your desired username and email ID.

1Initialize Local Git Repository

Navigate to your local project directory using the VS Code CLI terminal and create a new local Git repository:

git init

2Commit Your Changes

Once the repository is initialized, you can commit your files. You have two options:

  • Using VS Code Source Control:

    Click on the 'Source Control' icon on the left navbar in VS Code. You should see your files ready to be committed. Click the 'Commit' button, provide a comment, stage your changes, and then commit the files.

  • Using CLI:

    Alternatively, run the following command in the terminal:

git commit -am "Your comment"

3Create a New GitHub Repository

Visit your GitHub account and create a new repository.

⚠️ Important:When creating the repository, do not create a 'README.md', '.gitignore' file, or add any license to the repo. These settings can sometimes cause issues during the initial push.

After creating the repository, copy its link.

4Connect Local and Remote Repositories and Push

Return to the terminal in VS Code and execute the following commands in succession:

git remote add origin <Link to GitHub Repo>// Maps the remote repository link to your local Git repository
git remote -v// Verify the link to your remote repository
git push -u origin master// Push your changes to the remote GitHub repository

📝 Note:If this is the first time your local Git account is connecting to GitHub, you may be prompted to enter your GitHub credentials in a separate window.

Firstly, I'll need a way to get the question name, it's leetcode link and the solution from the website.

the website is really sorted and has a solution page which divides the problems into 4 vategores,
  • Data Structures
  • Algorithms
  • System Design
  • Special Topics
Further, these topics are then divided into several sub-categories like tree, graph, hashing, stack, queue etc. etc.
I'll smply be using selenium and beautiful soup to get all the solutions from them.
Every page has tons of link to each question. Luckily, each link has the number and the name of question as it's text, that too inscribed in a single <ul> with multiple <li>. How noob of them, haha.

Got the code, using the webchrome-driver to get the website, using selenium to get all the question number and their name as well as the leetcode links. Guess that's a typical google thing. What I can think of is, one is used to add the UI part and other to add the functionality.
